intro: Matelea crispiflora, commonly known as the brittleleaf mallow, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton, and is characterized by its showy, trumpet-shaped flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and thrives in full sun to partial shade. Its leaves are often covered in fine, white hairs, giving it a silvery appearance. Matelea crispiflora is known for its ability to withstand drought and is often found in desert or arid environments.
